facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 115 and 116 of 1963 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 11 5 116 of 1963. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated July 9, 1958, September 24, 1958 of the Union of India  Ministry of Steel, Mines and Fuel, New Delhi  and the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi respectively.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from orders dated July 9, 1958 of Union of India Ministry of Steel, Mines and Fuel and September 24, 1958 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and orders dated July 9, 1958, September 24, 1958 of the Union of India  Ministry of Steel, Mines and Fuel, New Delhi  and the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi respectively. S. Pathak, Rameshwar Nath and S. N. Andley, for the. appellant  in both the appeals . G. Patwardhan and B. R. K. G. Achar, for respondent No. 1  in both the appeals .

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 115 is by special leave under Art. 136 against Union of India order dated July 9, 1958 rejecting application under rule 57 for review of Madhya Pradesh Government order rejecting renewal of Certificate of Approval.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 115 is by special leave granted by this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution and is against an order of the Union of India  Ministry of Steel, Mines and Fuel  dated July 9, 1958 rejecting an application filed by the appellants under rule 57 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 to review an order passed by the Government of Madhya Pradesh rejecting their application for the renewal of the Certificate of Approval granted to them.

facts.text: Appellants filed petition to Punjab High Court under Art. 226 for writ of certiorari to quash Union of India order, dismissed in limine.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a petition to the High Court Punjab under Art. 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ of certiorari to quash the above order of the Union of India. This petition was dismissed by the High Court in limine and Civil Appeal No. 116 of 1963 is by special leave of this Court against this order of the High Court, Punjab.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 116 of 1963 is by special leave against Punjab High Court order dismissing the petition.

anchor.surface_text: and Civil Appeal No. 116 of 1963 is by special leave of this Court against this order of the High Court, Punjab. It would thus be seen that both the appeals are directed to challenge the validity of the same order and we shall therefore deal with them together.

facts.text: Appellants constitute a partnership engaged inter alia in the business of mining.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants, who companystitute a partnership, are engaged inter alia in the business of mining and they held a prospecting licence in the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: Appellants held a prospecting licence in the State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: and they held a prospecting licence in the State of Madhya Pradesh. They hold companycessions in regard to prospecting and working minerals in several areas of the State to the details of which it is number necessary to refer.

facts.text: Appellants obtained certificate of approval from Government of Madhya Pradesh under Mineral Concession Rules from 1952 onwards.

anchor.surface_text: To enable them to do the prospecting in lands in which they had obtained mineral companycessions, the appellants applied for and obtained from the Government of Madhya Pradesh a certificate of approval under the Mineral Concession Rules from 1952 onwards.

facts.text: Certificate of approval has duration of one calendar year and must be renewed every year.

anchor.surface_text: The duration of the certificate is one calendar year and the same has to be renewed every year, if it is to be in force.

facts.text: Appellants held valid certificate of approval up to December 31, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The original certificate granted to the appellants for the year 1952 was being renewed from year to year and as a result they held a valid certificate of approval up to the period ending on December 31, 1955.

facts.text: Appellants applied to Government of Madhya Pradesh for renewal of certificate for 1956 on November 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Being desirous of having the same renewed for the following calendar year 1956 they made an application to the Government of Madhya Pradesh on November 22, 1955.

facts.text: Application for renewal furnished required information, documents, and was recommended by District Officer, Bhandara.

anchor.surface_text: The information required by the form of application prescribed by the rules was furnished and the necessary documents were filed and this application was recommended by the District Officer, Bhandara.

facts.text: Government of Madhya Pradesh rejected the renewal application on September 21, 1956 because partners composing the firm had changed.

anchor.surface_text: The State Government, however, by an order dated September 21, 1956 rejected the application, the reason given being that the partners companyposing the firm had changed.

facts.text: Rejection order communicated to appellants on October 6, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This order was companymunicated to the appellants on October 6, 1956 and thereupon the appellants made an application on November 15, 1956 to the Union Government for a review

facts.text: Appellants applied to Union Government for review under rule 57 on November 15, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and thereupon the appellants made an application on November 15, 1956 to the Union Government for a review of the order of the State Government under rule 57 of the Mineral Concession Rules.

facts.text: Correspondence ensued between Central Government and Government of Madhya Pradesh regarding the review application.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter companyrespondence seems to have ensued between the Central Government and the Government of Madhya Pradesh in regard to the propriety of granting the application for review.

facts.text: Appellants requested information on progress and personal hearing after learning State Government was asked for report.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants having companye to know from a letter addressed to them by the Government of India that the State Government had been required to send a report of their remarks in companynection with their application for review made enquiries as to what had happened and also requested that they might be informed as to the progress of their application and that they might be given an opportunity of a personal hearing at which they would be able to satisfy the Government about the genuineness of their case.

facts.text: It is common ground that appellants were not informed of correspondence between Government of India and State Government prior to rejection order.

anchor.surface_text: Some portions of this companyrespondence between the Government of India. and the Government of the State as to the merits of the appellants application are number on record but it is companymon ground that the appellants were number informed of these documents prior to the order number impugned rejecting the application for review was passed.

facts.text: Union Government rejected the review application on July 9, 1958 stating no valid ground for interfering with Madhya Pradesh decision.

anchor.surface_text: On July 9, 1958 the application of the appellants was rejected by the Union Government, the order stating The Central Government have companye to the companyclusion that there is numbervalid ground for interfering with the decision of the Government of Madhya Pradesh rejecting your application for renewal of a certificate of approval for the year 1956.

facts.text: Appellants requested copy of State Government report, but Government of India refused.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereafter applied to the Government of India requesting for a companyy of the report of the State Government on the basis of which the application was rejected. The reply that the appellants received was that the Government of India regretted their inability to accede to their request.

facts.text: State Government refused renewal because there had been a change in composition of the firm which destroyed its identity.

anchor.surface_text: As we have already indicated, the State Government had refused renewal of the certificate of approval because they companysidered that there had been a change in the companyposition of the firm which destroyed its identity.

facts.text: Appellants claimed partnership deed provided for continuance of firm identity notwithstanding changes in partners.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, the case of the appellants was that the terms of the partnership deed made express provisions for the companytinuance of the identity of the firm, numberwithstanding changes in the persons companyposing the firm by death, retirement or because of the accession of new members to replace deceased or retiring partners or even otherwise.

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed Art. 226 petition because it viewed Central Government jurisdiction under rules 57 and 59 as administrative.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the Punjab High Court dismissed the petition filed before them under Art. 226, apparently be- cause they proceeded on the view that the exercise of jurisdiction of the Central Government under rules 57 and 59 of the Mineral Concession Rules was really administrative in character so that the reasonable opportunity that is an essential requisite of quasi-judicial procedure was number attracted to the  1  1960 2 S.C.R. 775. case.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 10, 1964 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: March 10, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-Civil Appeal No. 115 is by special leave granted by this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution and is against an order of the Union of India  Ministry of Steel, Mines and Fuel  dated July 9, 1958

facts.text: Court held Union Government order vitiated for violation of natural justice as appellants not given opportunity to meet State Government report.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore numberhesitation in holding that the order of the Central Government number under appeal is vitiated as being companytrary to the principles of natural justice, in that the decision was rendered without affording to the appellants a reasonable opportunity of being heard which is a sine qua number of a fair hearing.

concepts.unlisted_description: Distinguished from quasi-judicial; does not require natural justice principles like hearing opportunity.

issues.text: Whether the Union Government exercises quasi-judicial jurisdiction when disposing of an application for review under Rule 59 of the Mineral Concession Rules, 1949?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak, learned Counsel for the appellants, submitted that the Union Government when disposing of an application under s. 57 2  in terms of rule 59 is acting as a quasi- judicial authority and the order which was passed taking into consideration the report of the State Government and without their knowing the contents of the report and without affording them a reasonable opportunity of presenting their case was contrary to natural justice and was therefore void. In this connection learned Counsel relied on the decision of this Court Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India 1 . Mr. Pathak is well-founded in his submission as to the nature of the jurisdiction exercised by the Union Government when disposing of an application for review under Rule 59 and the decision referred

issues.text: Whether the order of the Central Government rejecting the review application is vitiated by violation of the principles of natural justice for failure to disclose the State Government's report and afford a hearing?

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondent-Union of India, did not seek to support the position taken by the Central Government that they were justified in refusing to disclose the contents of the report they obtained from the State Government which afforded them the factual basis on which they rejected the application for review. We have therefore no hesitation in holding that the order of the Central Government now under appeal is vitiated as being contrary to the principles of natural justice, in that the decision was rendered without affording to the appellants a reasonable opportunity of being heard which is a sine qua non of a fair hearing.

issues.text: Whether the Punjab High Court erred in dismissing the writ petition under Article 226 on the ground that the Central Government's jurisdiction under Rules 57 and 59 is administrative?

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the Punjab High Court dismissed the petition filed before them under Art. 226, apparently because they proceeded on the view that the exercise of jurisdiction of the Central Government under rules 57 and 59 of the Mineral Concession Rules was really administrative in character so that the reasonable opportunity that is an essential requisite of quasi-judicial procedure was not attracted to the case. That was the view taken by that Court in the Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India and Ors. 1  which decision was reversed by this Court.

arguments.claim: Union Government when disposing of an application under rule 57 in terms of rule 59 is acting as a quasi-judicial authority and the order was contrary to natural justice because it considered the State Government report without disclosing its contents to appellants or affording them a reasonable opportunity to present their case, rendering it void.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak, learned Counsel for the appellants, submitted that the Union Government when disposing of an application under s. 57 2  in terms of rule 59 is acting as a quasi- judicial authority and the order which was passed taking into companysideration the report of the State Government and without their knowing the companytents of the report and without affording them a reasonable opportunity of presenting their case was companytrary to natural justice and was therefore void. In this companynection learned Counsel relied on the decision of this Court Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India 1 .

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondent-Union of India, did number seek to support the position taken by the Central Government that they were justified in refusing to disclose the company- tents of the report they obtained from the State Government which afforded them the factual basis on which they rejected the application for review. We have therefore numberhesitation in holding that the order of the Central Government number under appeal is vitiated as being companytrary to the principles of natural justice, in that the decision was rendered without affording to the appellants a reasonable opportunity of being heard which is a sine qua number of a fair hearing.

anchor.surface_text: It does follow therefore that they companyld number act on the basis of material as regards which the appellants had numberopportunity to make their representation. No doubt, the decision in Shivji Nathubhai v The Union of India and Ors.  1  was companycerned with a case where an order had been passed prejudicial to the respondents before the Central Government without affording them an opportunity to meet the case of an applicant for review but the same principle would, in our opinion, apply even where a petition for review is rejected based on materials which were number made available to the applicant for review.

holdings.text: The Union Government when disposing of an application for review under Rule 59 of the Mineral Concession Rules is functioning as a quasi-judicial authority.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak is well-founded in his submission as to the nature of the jurisdiction exercised by the Union Government when disposing of an application for review under Rule 59 and the decision referred to does  1  1960 2 S.C.R. 775. support him that the Central Government acting under the rule referred to is functioning as a quasi-judicial authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner's submission accepted based on precedent in Shivji Nathubhai v. Union of India, where similar jurisdiction held quasi-judicial.

holdings.text: The principle requiring opportunity to meet adverse material applies even where a petition for review is rejected based on materials not made available to the applicant.

anchor.surface_text: It does follow therefore that they could not act on the basis of material as regards which the appellants had no opportunity to make their representation. No doubt, the decision in Shivji Nathubhai v The Union of India and Ors.  1  was concerned with a case where an order had been passed prejudicial to the respondents before the Central Government without affording them an opportunity to meet the case of an applicant for review but the same principle would, in our opinion, apply even where a petition for review is rejected based on materials which were not made available to the applicant for review.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy from Shivji precedent extended to rejection of review applications, requiring disclosure of materials like State report.

holdings.text: The order of the Central Government rejecting the review application is vitiated as contrary to principles of natural justice for failure to afford reasonable opportunity of being heard by not disclosing State Government report.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondent-Union of India, did not seek to support the position taken by the Central Government that they were justified in refusing to disclose the contents of the report they obtained from the State Government which afforded them the factual basis on which they rejected the application for review. We have therefore no hesitation in holding that the order of the Central Government now under appeal is vitiated as being contrary to the principles of natural justice, in that the decision was rendered without affording to the appellants a reasonable opportunity of being heard which is a sine qua non of a fair hearing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Quasi-judicial authority must disclose adverse material (State report) and give hearing; respondent concedes no justification for non-disclosure; appellants entitled to rebut points against their case.

holdings.text: The Punjab High Court erred in dismissing the writ petition on the view that Central Government jurisdiction under Rules 57 and 59 is administrative, as that view was reversed by this Court in Shivji Nathubhai.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the Punjab High Court dismissed the petition filed before them under Art. 226, apparently because they proceeded on the view that the exercise of jurisdiction of the Central Government under rules 57 and 59 of the Mineral Concession Rules was really administrative in character so that the reasonable opportunity that is an essential requisite of quasi-judicial procedure was not attracted to the  1  1960 2 S.C.R. 775. case. That was the view taken by that Court in the Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India and Ors.  1  which decision was reversed by this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court's view characterized jurisdiction as administrative, not requiring natural justice; directly contradicted by Supreme Court's reversal in Shivji precedent.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Pathak is well-founded in his submission as to the nature of the jurisdiction exercised by the Union Government when disposing of an application for review under Rule 59 and the decision referred to does  1  1960 2 S.C.R. 775. support him that the Central Government acting under the rule referred to is functioning as a quasi-judicial authority.

We have therefore numberhesitation in holding that the order of the Central Government number under appeal is vitiated as being companytrary to the principles of natural justice, in that the decision was rendered without affording to the appellants a reasonable opportunity of being

edges.explanation: h2 establishes that opportunity to meet adverse material applies even in review rejections, supporting h3's vitiation for failure to disclose.

anchor.surface_text: It does follow therefore that they could not act on the basis of material as regards which the appellants had no opportunity to make their representation. No doubt, the decision in Shivji Nathubhai v The Union of India and Ors.  1  was concerned with a case where an order had been passed prejudicial to the respondents before the Central Government without affording them an opportunity to meet the case of an applicant for review but the same principle would, in our opinion, apply even where a petition for review is rejected based on materials which were not made available to the applicant for review.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondent-Union of India, did not seek to support the position taken by the Central Government that they were justified in refusing to disclose the contents of the report they obtained from the State Government which afforded them the factual basis on which they rejected the application for review. We have therefore no hesitation in holding that the order of the Central Government now under appeal is vitiated as being contrary to the principles of natural justice, in that the decision was rendered without affording to the appellants a reasonable opportunity of being heard which is a sine qua non of a fair hearing.

We have therefore numberhesitation in holding that the order of the Central Government number under appeal is vitiated as being companytrary to the principles of natural justice, in that the decision was rendered without affording to the appellants a reasonable opportunity of being

edges.explanation: The holding directly responds to the issue by affirming that 'The Punjab High Court erred in dismissing the writ petition...', matching the question of whether it erred.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the Punjab High Court dismissed the petition filed before them under Art. 226, apparently because they proceeded on the view that the exercise of jurisdiction of the Central Government under rules 57 and 59 of the Mineral Concession Rules was really administrative in character so that the reasonable opportunity that is an essential requisite of quasi-judicial procedure was not attracted to the  1  1960 2 S.C.R. 775. case. That was the view taken by that Court in the Shivji Nathubhai v. The Union of India and Ors.  1  which decision was reversed by this Court.

We have therefore numberhesitation in holding that the order of the Central Government number under appeal is vitiated as being companytrary to the principles of natural justice, in that the decision was rendered without affording to the appellants a reasonable opportunity of being
